entry.title: Ozone: Custom Analog Wrist Watch
entry.content:
I recently finished designing and assembling Ozone, a custom wrist watch for daily wear. Ozone is not only my first attempt at making a watch, but also my first mechanically-oriented project where aesthetics are the focus. Most of my other projects are focussed on function. Overall, I am pleased with how it came out.

I have intentionally kept Ozone very simple. The watch does not have any complications to tell you the month, date, or day of the week. It does not have any buttons or usable moving parts except for the crown. All it does is tell you the current hour and minute. I will likely make another watch in the future, and on that one, maybe include some other useful functionality. But for now, this was the right place to start.

While I designed and sourced everything in the watch, it was not feasible for me to manufacture everything. For example, while I designed the watch case, it was machined by JLC. The dial and internal retention pieces were simple enough to design and 3D print on my own. Smaller pieces such as the crown, watch hands, and movement, were sourced and purchased individually.

What follows are some notes on the project. These are meant as a reference for future-me, in case I decide to make another watch. But maybe someone else will find them interesting.

Anatomy of my Watch

Ozone is composed of the following parts:

  1. The watch mechanism (called the “movement”)
  2. The movement retainer
  3. The front case
  4. The rear case
  5. The stem, crown, and crown tube
  6. The dial and hands
  7. The crystal and its gasket

Let’s explore the major parts in more detail.

The Case

I kept Ozone’s case very simple from both an aesthetic and mechanical point of view. The case was designed to be 38mm in diameter, which is a common size for men’s watches, with 22mm lugs. The lugs extend out from the watch by 4.5mm. These dimensions more-or-less match the dimensions of a cheap watch that seemed the right size for me.

I guessed on the shape of the lugs’ side profile, and then iterated on the design by 3D printing and making adjustments until I liked it.

The body of the front case is broken into three regions: The movement cavity, the display area, and the bezel. The movement cavity is where the watch movement and dial sit inside the case. The display area is where the watch hands live. The bezel holds the crystal and crystal gasket into place.

The movement cavity is 30 mm in diameter and 3.59 mm thick. This is about 0.2 mm thicker than the expected combined thickness of the movement and dial. This is important; as dicussed later, the rear case helps keep everything in place.

The display area has a diameter of 27.3 mm, which is large enough to comfortably fit whatever dial markings and hands I want. The area is 2.18 mm thick, just slightly thicker than the recommendation from my movement’s datasheet. The transition from the movement cavity to the display area forms a small lip that the dial sits on when installed.

The inner-diameter of the bezel is 29.2mm, which is 8.8mm smaller than the outer diameter of the case. If I end up making a second version of the watch, I’ll probably make the bezel thinner by increasing the inner-diameter so I can fit a larger crystal into the same case footprint.

The side of the case has a 2.1mm hole drilled through it for the watch stem and crown tube. A crown tube is press fit into the hole. The case-end of the tube is 2.2 mm in diameter, the crown end is 2.5 mm, and the total length is 4.9 mm.

On many watches, the rear of the of the watch screws into the case and is sealed by a gasket to prevent water from entering. To change the battery, all you need to do is unscrew the back. Or, the rear snaps onto the front case and can be removed by prying it open with a thin screw driver. This allows for the rear case to be attached to the front case without screws. Because this was my first time designing a part that would be CNC machined, I wasn’t overly confident and wanted to keep my attachment method simple. So instead, I opted to to make the rear case secure to the front case by four M1.4 screws (often used for glasses). The result is less slick, but is only visible when the watch is upside down and off my wrist, which doesn’t happen much. Also, I kinda dig the look.

I had the case machined out of aluminum, bead blasted, and then annodized by JLC. I left the part a “natural” matte color. This gave the watch case an industrial look, which I am a fan of, but I also think it’d look great if it were sanded and polished. On a future revision of the watch, I may order a second one and take the the time to detail the case. This would hopefully give a nice, refined look.

The Movement and Retainer

At the heart of Ozone is a Y121E Type S quartz movement from Epson. It’s a cheap movement readily available on esslinger that promises a battery life of about two years. The movement is meant for low-cost watches and offers an accuracy that reflects that: ±\pm± 20 seconds per month. That seems to be pretty standard for cheap quartz watches, and is fine by me. I’m not building a chronometer.

The movement datasheet says it is 15.3 mm long in the 3-9H direction and 18.2 mm long in the 6-12H direction. This makes it comfortably smaller than a US nickel. The movement casing is 2.99 mm thick, but the center posts (for the hands) extend the overall thickness up to 4.42 mm. Other variations of the Y121E have the same case dimensions but different center post lengths, which allows them to fit watches with thicker dials.

The front of the movement has a variety of holes but, from what I can tell, only three of them are intended to be used for mounting purposes (more on that later). The rear face of the movement has a battery compartment and a small mechanism that you push with a screw driver to install or remove the stem.

In these pictures, the movement is rotated counter-clockwise by 90°\degree° from how it’d normally be on your wrist. The 3H direction as at the top of the pictures.

The mounting holes are not meant for directly mounting the movement to the case. Instead, the dial is supposed to have feet that go into the movement’s mounting holes, joining the two. The dial and movement then sit, as a unit, inside the case. To more securely hold the movement in place, a plastic retention piece is used. The retention piece pushes against the case walls, keeping the movement in place and reducing the chances of the small feet shearing off the dial. Finally, the rear case is installed and holds everything from the back.

I printed the retention piece from PLA and designed it so that it needs to be slightly compressed to fit into the case. This makes for a very snug fit.

That’s how things are supposed to go. In Ozone, there aren’t any feet holding the dial and movement together. Everything is held in place by compression. The dial ended up being more challenging than I expected.

The Dial

One of the more challenging parts of the project ended up being the watch dial. As mentioned above, dials usually have feet that slot into dedicated mounting holes in the movement, joining the two together. My original plan was to find dial blanks with feet that fit my movement, to paint the blanks, and then use waterslide paper to create the dial pattern. However, I couldn’t find any dial blanks with feet that fit. I had expected this would be the case, so my backup option was going to be to buy normal blanks and try soldering feet to them. I was unsure how reliably I could get the feet aligned and firmly attached, but I thought I’d try since I had seen others do it online. But when I went to add dial blanks to my Esslinger cart during an order, the dial blanks I had planned to purchase turned out to be unavailable.

Frustrated, I decided to try something different. I 3D printed a thin dial, without feet, on my FDM printer. I then did some light surface preparation and spray painted the part white. Finally, I used waterslide paper to transfer my dial pattern onto the printed part. To install the dial, I used a small piece of double-sided tape to keep the movement and dial “secured” and then carefully installed them as a unit. Without the feet, it was critical to get the rotation of the dial and movement correct on the first try.

The resulting dial works well enough that I can wear the watch, but it is not amazing. When quickly checking the time, it looks okay. But under close inspection, you can see multiple defects in the dial. Because my surface prep was rushed, when looking at the dial closely, you can see that the surface is not perfectly smooth. This has also resulted in the waterslide paper losing cohesion with the dial and small air pockets forming. These defects actually aren’t noticeable during everyday wear. But they are obvious under any amount of scrutiny.

Another problem with this technique has to do with the waterslide paper. When printed, I noticed small white cracks forming in the middle of the ink. I tried a few different ways of eliminating these, such as playing with printer settings, but I haven’t been successful. The internet implies that this could be caused by low quality waterslide paper. These are, again, not really visible during normal wear and are only noticed when inspecting the watch.

I am currently exploring some other options for manufacturing the dial. I considered metal FDM printing the dials, which would also allow me to emboss the dial marks, but ran into problems with the necessary thickness of the dial. I cannot easily change the dial thickness without ordering a new case because of the part tolerances. Currently, I am talking to small laser engraving businesses in my area to see if laser engraved aluminum would be feasible. I’ll update this write-up when I finally have a solution to my liking.

entry.title: Short Dipole Antenna
entry.content:
On This Page

A variety of notes and equations specific to a short dipole antenna.

  • What is an Short Dipole Antenna?
  • Summary of Equations
  • Far-Field Radiation
    • Magnetic Vector Potential
    • Magnetic Field
    • Electric Field
    • Normalized Radiation and Power Patterns
    • Radiation Intensity
  • Directivity

A note on notation: All vector quantities will have a bar over them while scalar quantities will not. Unit vectors will be represented with a hat (e.g., x^\hat{x}x^) instead of a bar. Therefore, Aˉ=Bx^\bar{A}=B\hat{x}Aˉ=Bx^ describes a vector called Aˉ\bar{A}Aˉ pointing in the x-direction with a magnitude of BBB.

What is an Short Dipole Antenna?

A dipole antenna is any antenna that creates a radiation pattern similar to the pattern that would be generated by two charges separated by some distance (in other words: a dipole). Dipole antennas are frequently created using two conductors placed at some angle to each other. For example, the “bunny ears” on older TVs are dipole antennas.

For the purpose of these notes, a dipole antenna will be constructed of two conductors separated from each other by 180°180\degree180°. The antenna will be center-fed.

– PICTURE –

A short dipole antenna is a dipole antenna that has a length much less than the wavelength of radiated wave. It can be thought of as the more-realistic form of an ideal dipole antenna. Importantly, it does not have a uniform current distribution along the antenna.

– PICTURE –

Summary of Equations

A summary of useful expressions that apply to short dipole antennas is provided below. Select derivations are provided in following sections.

Note: The far-field results tabulated below assume a short dipole antenna centered at the origin and aligned with the z-axis.

Far-Field Property Expression
Magnetic Field Hˉ≈ϕ^jksin⁡θI0Le−jkr8πr\bar{H}\approx\hat{\phi}\frac{jk\sin\theta I_0Le^{-jkr}}{8\pi r}Hˉ≈ϕ^​8πrjksinθI0​Le−jkr​
Electric Field Eˉ≈θ^kηsin⁡θI0Le−jkr8πr\bar{E}\approx\hat{\theta} \frac{k\eta\sin\theta I_0Le^{-jkr}}{8\pi r}Eˉ≈θ^8πrkηsinθI0​Le−jkr​
Radiation Pattern f(θ,ϕ)≈sin⁡θf(\theta,\phi)\approx\sin\thetaf(θ,ϕ)≈sinθ
Power Pattern F(θ,ϕ)≈sin⁡2θF(\theta,\phi)\approx\sin^2\thetaF(θ,ϕ)≈sin2θ
Radiation Intensity U(θ,ϕ)≈k2η2(I0L8π)2sin⁡2θU(\theta, \phi) \approx \frac{k^2\eta}{2}\left(\frac{I_0L}{8\pi}\right)^2\sin^2\thetaU(θ,ϕ)≈2k2η​(8πI0​L​)2sin2θ
Other Parameters Expression
Directivity D(θ,ϕ)=32sin⁡2θD(\theta, \phi) = \frac{3}{2}\sin^2\thetaD(θ,ϕ)=23​sin2θ

Far-Field Radiation

Magnetic Vector Potential

Expand for Details To find the far-field electric- and magnetic-fields for a short dipole antenna placed at the origin, aligned with the z-axis, and fed a sinusoidal current, first find the magnetic vector potential of the antenna. Aˉ(x′,y′,z′)=z^μ4π∫L/2−L/2I(z)e−jkRRdz′\begin{aligned} \bar{A}(x', y', z') & = \hat{z}\frac{\mu}{4\pi}\int_{L/2}^{-L/2} \frac{I(z)e^{-jkR}}{R} dz' \end{aligned}Aˉ(x′,y′,z′)​=z^4πμ​∫L/2−L/2​RI(z)e−jkR​dz′​ Where kkk is the wave-number of the radiated wave, LLL is the length of the antenna, I(z)I(z)I(z) is the current along the antenna as a function of zzz, and RRR is the distance between some point along the antenna and the observation location. That is: R=(x−x′)2+(y−y′)2+(z−z′)2=x2+y2+(z−z′)2R = \sqrt{(x-x')^2 + (y-y')^2 + (z-z')^2} = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2 + (z-z')^2}R=(x−x′)2+(y−y′)2+(z−z′)2​=x2+y2+(z−z′)2​ Because the dipole is short (L≪λ)(L\ll\lambda)(L≪λ), R=x2+y2+(z−z′)2≈x2+y2+z2=rR=\sqrt{x^2+y^2+(z-z')^2}\approx\sqrt{x^2+y^2+z^2}=rR=x2+y2+(z−z′)2​≈x2+y2+z2​=r. Further, the current distribution can be approximated as a line instead of a sinusoid. -- PICTURE -- Letting I(z)=I0(1−2∣z′∣L)I(z)=I_0\left(1-2\frac{\left|z'\right|}{L}\right)I(z)=I0​(1−2L∣z′∣​) simplifies the magnetic vector potential equation. Aˉ(x′,y′,z′)=z^μ4π∫L/2−L/2I(z)e−jkRRdz′≈z^μ4π∫L/2−L/2I0(1−2∣z′∣L)e−jkrrdz′≈z^12μI0Lπre−jkr\begin{aligned} \bar{A}(x', y', z') & = \hat{z}\frac{\mu}{4\pi}\int_{L/2}^{-L/2} \frac{I(z)e^{-jkR}}{R} dz' \\ & \approx \hat{z}\frac{\mu}{4\pi}\int_{L/2}^{-L/2} \frac{I_0\left(1-2\frac{\left|z'\right|}{L}\right)e^{-jkr}}{r} dz' \\ & \approx \hat{z}\frac{1}{2}\frac{\mu I_0 L}{\pi r}e^{-jkr} \end{aligned}Aˉ(x′,y′,z′)​=z^4πμ​∫L/2−L/2​RI(z)e−jkR​dz′≈z^4πμ​∫L/2−L/2​rI0​(1−2L∣z′∣​)e−jkr​dz′≈z^21​πrμI0​L​e−jkr​ Note that the magnetic vector potential is half that of the ideal dipole antenna. In the spherical coordinate system: Aˉ(r,θ,ϕ)=Az[r^cos⁡θ−θ^sin⁡θ]\bar{A}(r, \theta, \phi) = A_z\left[\hat{r}\cos\theta - \hat{\theta}\sin\theta\right]Aˉ(r,θ,ϕ)=Az​[r^cosθ−θ^sinθ]

Magnetic Field

Expand for Details Using the magnetic vector potential, Aˉ\bar{A}Aˉ, compute the magnetic field. Hˉ=1μ∇×Aˉ=∣r^r2sin⁡θθrsin⁡θϕr∂∂r∂∂θ∂∂ϕArrAθrsin⁡θAϕ∣=ϕ^1μr(∂∂rrAθ−∂∂θAr)=ϕ^12sin⁡θI0Le−jkr4π[jkr+1r2]\begin{aligned} \bar{H} = \frac{1}{\mu}\nabla\times\bar{A} & = \begin{vmatrix} \frac{\hat{r}}{r^2\sin\theta} & \frac{\theta}{r\sin\theta} & \frac{\phi}{r} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial r} & \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta} & \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi} \\ A_r & rA_\theta & r\sin\theta A_\phi \end{vmatrix} \\ & = \hat{\phi}\frac{1}{\mu r}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial r}rA_\theta - \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}A_r\right) \\ & = \hat{\phi}\frac{1}{2}\frac{\sin\theta I_0 L e^{-jkr}}{4\pi} \left[\frac{jk}{r} + \frac{1}{r^2}\right] \end{aligned}Hˉ=μ1​∇×Aˉ​=∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​r2sinθr^​∂r∂​Ar​​rsinθθ​∂θ∂​rAθ​​rϕ​∂ϕ∂​rsinθAϕ​​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​=ϕ^​μr1​(∂r∂​rAθ​−∂θ∂​Ar​)=ϕ^​21​4πsinθI0​Le−jkr​[rjk​+r21​]​ Because we are looking for the far-field radiation, 1/r1/r1/r is much greater than 1/r21/r^21/r2. The magnetic field can be approximated as: Hˉ≈ϕ^jksin⁡θI0Le−jkr8πr \bar{H} \approx \hat{\phi}jk\sin\theta\frac{I_0Le^{-jkr}}{8\pi r} Hˉ≈ϕ^​jksinθ8πrI0​Le−jkr​

Electric Field

Expand for Details To find the electric field, compute: Eˉ=−jωAˉ−jωμϵ∇(∇⋅Aˉ)\bar{E}=-j\omega\bar{A} - \frac{j}{\omega\mu\epsilon}\nabla\left(\nabla\cdot\bar{A}\right)Eˉ=−jωAˉ−ωμϵj​∇(∇⋅Aˉ) After much tedious math (which I am choosing to not do, for now): Eˉ≈θ^kηsin⁡θI0Le−jkr8πr \bar{E} \approx \hat{\theta}k\eta\sin\theta\frac{I_0Le^{-jkr}}{8\pi r} Eˉ≈θ^kηsinθ8πrI0​Le−jkr​

Normalized Radiation and Power Patterns

Expand for Details The normalized radiation pattern, f(θ,ϕ)f(\theta, \phi)f(θ,ϕ), is simply the magnitude of the far-field electric field divided by its maximum value. f(θ,ϕ)=∣Eˉ(θ,ϕ)∣max∣Eˉ∣=sin⁡θ f(\theta, \phi) = \frac{\left| \bar{E}(\theta,\phi) \right|}{\text{max}\left|\bar{E}\right|} = \sin\theta f(θ,ϕ)=max∣∣∣​Eˉ∣∣∣​∣∣∣​Eˉ(θ,ϕ)∣∣∣​​=sinθ The normalized power pattern, F(θ,ϕ)F(\theta,\phi)F(θ,ϕ), is the squared magnitude of f(θ,ϕ)f(\theta, \phi)f(θ,ϕ). F(θ,ϕ)=∣f(θ,ϕ)∣2=sin⁡2θ F(\theta, \phi) = \left|f(\theta, \phi)\right|^2 = \sin^2\theta F(θ,ϕ)=∣f(θ,ϕ)∣2=sin2θ

Radiation Intensity

Expand for Details To find the radiation intensity, or power radiated in a given direction for a unit solid angle, first compute the real-component radiated fields' Poynting vector (power flow density). Sˉr(r,θ,ϕ)=Real(12Eˉ×Hˉ∗)=r^k2η2(I0L8π)2(sin⁡θr)2\begin{aligned} \bar{S}_r(r, \theta, \phi) & = \text{Real}\left(\frac{1}{2}\bar{E}\times\bar{H}^*\right) \\ & = \hat{r}\frac{k^2\eta}{2}\left(\frac{I_0L}{8\pi}\right)^2\left(\frac{\sin\theta}{r}\right)^2 \end{aligned}Sˉr​(r,θ,ϕ)​=Real(21​Eˉ×Hˉ∗)=r^2k2η​(8πI0​L​)2(rsinθ​)2​ Now, compute the radiation intensity. U(θ,ϕ)=Sˉr(r,θ,ϕ)⋅(r2r^)=k2η2(I0L8π)2sin⁡2θ U(\theta, \phi) = \bar{S}_r(r, \theta, \phi)\cdot \left(r^2\hat{r}\right) = \frac{k^2\eta}{2}\left(\frac{I_0L}{8\pi}\right)^2\sin^2\theta U(θ,ϕ)=Sˉr​(r,θ,ϕ)⋅(r2r^)=2k2η​(8πI0​L​)2sin2θ Because it will be useful later, I will also compute the average radiation intensity. To do so, sum the radiation intensity and divide by the surface area of the sphere with length rrr. Uavg=∫∫U(θ,ϕ)dΩ∫∫dΩ=∫∫U(θ,ϕ)sin⁡θdθdϕ∫∫sin⁡θdθdϕ=k2ηI02L2192π2\begin{aligned} U_{avg} & = \frac{\int\int U(\theta, \phi) d\Omega}{\int\int d\Omega} \\ & = \frac{\int\int U(\theta, \phi) \sin\theta d\theta d\phi}{\int\int \sin\theta d\theta d\phi} \\ & = \frac{k^2\eta I_0^2L^2}{192\pi^2} \end{aligned}Uavg​​=∫∫dΩ∫∫U(θ,ϕ)dΩ​=∫∫sinθdθdϕ∫∫U(θ,ϕ)sinθdθdϕ​=192π2k2ηI02​L2​​

Directivity

Expand for Details To find directivity of a short dipole antenna as a function of θ\thetaθ and ϕ\phiϕ, divide the antenna's radiation intensity by its average value. D(θ,ϕ)=k2η2(I0L8π)2sin⁡2θk2ηI02L2192π2=32sin⁡2θ\begin{aligned} D(\theta, \phi) = \frac{\frac{k^2\eta}{2}\left(\frac{I_0L}{8\pi}\right)^2\sin^2\theta}{\frac{k^2\eta I_0^2L^2}{192\pi^2}} = \frac{3}{2}\sin^2\theta \end{aligned}D(θ,ϕ)=192π2k2ηI02​L2​2k2η​(8πI0​L​)2sin2θ​=23​sin2θ​

entry.title: Ideal Dipole Antenna
entry.content:
On This Page

A variety of notes and equations specific to an ideal dipole antenna.

  • What is an Ideal Dipole Antenna?
  • Summary of Equations
  • Far-Field Radiation
    • Magnetic Vector Potential
    • Magnetic Field
    • Electric Field
    • Normalized Radiation and Power Patterns
    • Radiation Intensity
  • Directivity and Gain

A note on notation: All vector quantities will have a bar over them while scalar quantities will not. Unit vectors will be represented with a hat (e.g., x^\hat{x}x^) instead of a bar. Therefore, Aˉ=Bx^\bar{A}=B\hat{x}Aˉ=Bx^ describes a vector called Aˉ\bar{A}Aˉ pointing in the x-direction with a magnitude of BBB.

What is an Ideal Dipole Antenna?

A dipole antenna is any antenna that creates a radiation pattern similar to the pattern that would be generated by two charges separated by some distance (in other words: a dipole). Dipole antennas are frequently created using two conductors placed at some angle to each other. For example, the “bunny ears” on older TVs are dipole antennas.

For the purpose of these notes, a dipole antenna will be constructed of two conductors separated from each other by 180°180\degree180°. The antenna will be center-fed.

– PICTURE –

An ideal dipole antenna (or: infinitesimal dipole) is a dipole antenna that has no loss, has a uniform current distribution across its conductors, and has a length much less than the wavelength of radiated wave.

– PICTURE –

Summary of Equations

A summary of useful expressions that apply to ideal dipole antennas is provided below. Select derivations are provided in following sections.

Note: The far-field results tabulated below assume an ideal dipole antenna centered at the origin and aligned with the z-axis.

Far-Field Property Expression
Magnetic Field Hˉ≈ϕ^jksin⁡θI0Le−jkr4πr\bar{H}\approx\hat{\phi}\frac{jk\sin\theta I_0Le^{-jkr}}{4\pi r}Hˉ≈ϕ^​4πrjksinθI0​Le−jkr​
Electric Field Eˉ≈θ^kηsin⁡θI0Le−jkr4πr\bar{E}\approx\hat{\theta} \frac{k\eta\sin\theta I_0Le^{-jkr}}{4\pi r}Eˉ≈θ^4πrkηsinθI0​Le−jkr​
Radiation Pattern f(θ,ϕ)≈sin⁡θf(\theta,\phi)\approx\sin\thetaf(θ,ϕ)≈sinθ
Power Pattern F(θ,ϕ)≈sin⁡2θF(\theta,\phi)\approx\sin^2\thetaF(θ,ϕ)≈sin2θ
Radiation Intensity U(θ,ϕ)≈k2η2(I0L4π)2sin⁡2θU(\theta, \phi) \approx \frac{k^2\eta}{2}\left(\frac{I_0L}{4\pi}\right)^2\sin^2\thetaU(θ,ϕ)≈2k2η​(4πI0​L​)2sin2θ
Other Parameters Expression
Directivity D(θ,ϕ)=32sin⁡2θD(\theta, \phi) = \frac{3}{2}\sin^2\thetaD(θ,ϕ)=23​sin2θ
Gain G(θ,ϕ)=32sin⁡2θG(\theta, \phi) = \frac{3}{2}\sin^2\thetaG(θ,ϕ)=23​sin2θ

Far-Field Radiation

Magnetic Vector Potential

Expand for Details To find the far-field electric- and magnetic-fields for an ideal dipole antenna placed at the origin and aligned with the z-axis, first find the magnetic vector potential of the antenna. Aˉ(x′,y′,z′)=z^μ4π∫L/2−L/2I(z)e−jkRRdz′\begin{aligned} \bar{A}(x', y', z') & = \hat{z}\frac{\mu}{4\pi}\int_{L/2}^{-L/2} \frac{I(z)e^{-jkR}}{R} dz' \end{aligned}Aˉ(x′,y′,z′)​=z^4πμ​∫L/2−L/2​RI(z)e−jkR​dz′​ Where kkk is the wave-number of the radiated wave, LLL is the length of the antenna, I(z)I(z)I(z) is the current along the antenna as a function of zzz, and RRR is the distance between some point along the antenna and the observation location. That is: R=(x−x′)2+(y−y′)2+(z−z′)2=x2+y2+(z−z′)2R = \sqrt{(x-x')^2 + (y-y')^2 + (z-z')^2} = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2 + (z-z')^2}R=(x−x′)2+(y−y′)2+(z−z′)2​=x2+y2+(z−z′)2​ Because the dipole is infinitesimally small, R=x2+y2+(z−z′)2≈x2+y2+z2=rR=\sqrt{x^2+y^2+(z-z')^2}\approx\sqrt{x^2+y^2+z^2}=rR=x2+y2+(z−z′)2​≈x2+y2+z2​=r. Further, because the current distributed along the antenna is constant, I(z)I(z)I(z) can be written as a constant value instead of a function of zzz. This greatly simplifies the magnetic vector potential equation. Aˉ(x′,y′,z′)=z^μ4π∫L/2−L/2I(z)e−jkRRdz′≈z^μ4π∫L/2−L/2I0e−jkrrdz′≈z^μI0L4πre−jkr\begin{aligned} \bar{A}(x', y', z') & = \hat{z}\frac{\mu}{4\pi}\int_{L/2}^{-L/2} \frac{I(z)e^{-jkR}}{R} dz' \\ & \approx \hat{z}\frac{\mu}{4\pi}\int_{L/2}^{-L/2} \frac{I_0e^{-jkr}}{r} dz' \\ & \approx \hat{z}\frac{\mu I_0 L}{4\pi r}e^{-jkr} \end{aligned}Aˉ(x′,y′,z′)​=z^4πμ​∫L/2−L/2​RI(z)e−jkR​dz′≈z^4πμ​∫L/2−L/2​rI0​e−jkr​dz′≈z^4πrμI0​L​e−jkr​ In the spherical coordinate system: Aˉ(r,θ,ϕ)=Az[r^cos⁡θ−θ^sin⁡θ]\bar{A}(r, \theta, \phi) = A_z\left[\hat{r}\cos\theta - \hat{\theta}\sin\theta\right]Aˉ(r,θ,ϕ)=Az​[r^cosθ−θ^sinθ]

Magnetic Field

Expand for Details Using the magnetic vector potential, Aˉ\bar{A}Aˉ, compute the magnetic field. Hˉ=1μ∇×Aˉ=∣r^r2sin⁡θθrsin⁡θϕr∂∂r∂∂θ∂∂ϕArrAθrsin⁡θAϕ∣=ϕ^1μr(∂∂rrAθ−∂∂θAr)=ϕ^sin⁡θI0Le−jkr4π[jkr+1r2]\begin{aligned} \bar{H} = \frac{1}{\mu}\nabla\times\bar{A} & = \begin{vmatrix} \frac{\hat{r}}{r^2\sin\theta} & \frac{\theta}{r\sin\theta} & \frac{\phi}{r} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial r} & \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta} & \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi} \\ A_r & rA_\theta & r\sin\theta A_\phi \end{vmatrix} \\ & = \hat{\phi}\frac{1}{\mu r}\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial r}rA_\theta - \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta}A_r\right) \\ & = \hat{\phi}\frac{\sin\theta I_0 L e^{-jkr}}{4\pi} \left[\frac{jk}{r} + \frac{1}{r^2}\right] \end{aligned}Hˉ=μ1​∇×Aˉ​=∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​r2sinθr^​∂r∂​Ar​​rsinθθ​∂θ∂​rAθ​​rϕ​∂ϕ∂​rsinθAϕ​​∣∣∣∣∣∣∣​=ϕ^​μr1​(∂r∂​rAθ​−∂θ∂​Ar​)=ϕ^​4πsinθI0​Le−jkr​[rjk​+r21​]​ Because we are looking for the far-field radiation, 1/r1/r1/r is much greater than 1/r21/r^21/r2. The magnetic field can be approximated as: Hˉ≈ϕ^jksin⁡θI0Le−jkr4πr \bar{H} \approx \hat{\phi}jk\sin\theta\frac{I_0Le^{-jkr}}{4\pi r} Hˉ≈ϕ^​jksinθ4πrI0​Le−jkr​

Electric Field

Expand for Details To find the electric field, compute: Eˉ=−jωAˉ−jωμϵ∇(∇⋅Aˉ)\bar{E}=-j\omega\bar{A} - \frac{j}{\omega\mu\epsilon}\nabla\left(\nabla\cdot\bar{A}\right)Eˉ=−jωAˉ−ωμϵj​∇(∇⋅Aˉ) After much tedious math (which I am choosing to not do, for now): Eˉ≈θ^kηsin⁡θI0Le−jkr4πr \bar{E} \approx \hat{\theta}k\eta\sin\theta\frac{I_0Le^{-jkr}}{4\pi r} Eˉ≈θ^kηsinθ4πrI0​Le−jkr​

Normalized Radiation and Power Patterns

Expand for Details The normalized radiation pattern, f(θ,ϕ)f(\theta, \phi)f(θ,ϕ), is simply the magnitude of the far-field electric field divided by its maximum value. f(θ,ϕ)=∣Eˉ(θ,ϕ)∣max∣Eˉ∣=sin⁡θ f(\theta, \phi) = \frac{\left| \bar{E}(\theta,\phi) \right|}{\text{max}\left|\bar{E}\right|} = \sin\theta f(θ,ϕ)=max∣∣∣​Eˉ∣∣∣​∣∣∣​Eˉ(θ,ϕ)∣∣∣​​=sinθ The normalized power pattern, F(θ,ϕ)F(\theta,\phi)F(θ,ϕ), is the squared magnitude of f(θ,ϕ)f(\theta, \phi)f(θ,ϕ). F(θ,ϕ)=∣f(θ,ϕ)∣2=sin⁡2θ F(\theta, \phi) = \left|f(\theta, \phi)\right|^2 = \sin^2\theta F(θ,ϕ)=∣f(θ,ϕ)∣2=sin2θ

Radiation Intensity

Expand for Details To find the radiation intensity, or power radiated in a given direction for a unit solid angle, first compute the real-component radiated fields' Poynting vector (power flow density). Sˉr(r,θ,ϕ)=Real(12Eˉ×Hˉ∗)=r^k2η2(I0L4π)2(sin⁡θr)2\begin{aligned} \bar{S}_r(r, \theta, \phi) & = \text{Real}\left(\frac{1}{2}\bar{E}\times\bar{H}^*\right) \\ & = \hat{r}\frac{k^2\eta}{2}\left(\frac{I_0L}{4\pi}\right)^2\left(\frac{\sin\theta}{r}\right)^2 \end{aligned}Sˉr​(r,θ,ϕ)​=Real(21​Eˉ×Hˉ∗)=r^2k2η​(4πI0​L​)2(rsinθ​)2​ Now, compute the radiation intensity. U(θ,ϕ)=Sˉr(r,θ,ϕ)⋅(r2r^)=k2η2(I0L4π)2sin⁡2θ U(\theta, \phi) = \bar{S}_r(r, \theta, \phi)\cdot \left(r^2\hat{r}\right) = \frac{k^2\eta}{2}\left(\frac{I_0L}{4\pi}\right)^2\sin^2\theta U(θ,ϕ)=Sˉr​(r,θ,ϕ)⋅(r2r^)=2k2η​(4πI0​L​)2sin2θ Because it will be useful later, I will also compute the average radiation intensity. To do so, sum the radiation intensity and divide by the surface area of the sphere with length rrr. Uavg=∫∫U(θ,ϕ)dΩ∫∫dΩ=∫∫U(θ,ϕ)sin⁡θdθdϕ∫∫sin⁡θdθdϕ=k2ηI02L248π2\begin{aligned} U_{avg} & = \frac{\int\int U(\theta, \phi) d\Omega}{\int\int d\Omega} \\ & = \frac{\int\int U(\theta, \phi) \sin\theta d\theta d\phi}{\int\int \sin\theta d\theta d\phi} \\ & = \frac{k^2\eta I_0^2L^2}{48\pi^2} \end{aligned}Uavg​​=∫∫dΩ∫∫U(θ,ϕ)dΩ​=∫∫sinθdθdϕ∫∫U(θ,ϕ)sinθdθdϕ​=48π2k2ηI02​L2​​

Directivity and Gain

Expand for Details To find directivity of an ideal dipole antenna as a function of θ\thetaθ and ϕ\phiϕ, divide the antenna's radiation intensity by its average value. D(θ,ϕ)=k2η2(I0L4π)2sin⁡2θk2ηI02L248π2=32sin⁡2θ\begin{aligned} D(\theta, \phi) = \frac{\frac{k^2\eta}{2}\left(\frac{I_0L}{4\pi}\right)^2\sin^2\theta}{\frac{k^2\eta I_0^2L^2}{48\pi^2}} = \frac{3}{2}\sin^2\theta \end{aligned}D(θ,ϕ)=48π2k2ηI02​L2​2k2η​(4πI0​L​)2sin2θ​=23​sin2θ​ Because an ideal dipole antenna is lossless, it has 100%100\%100% efficiency. Therefore, it's gain is: G(θ,ϕ)=erD(θ,ϕ)=32sin⁡2θ\begin{aligned} G(\theta, \phi) = e_rD(\theta, \phi) = \frac{3}{2}\sin^2\theta \end{aligned}G(θ,ϕ)=er​D(θ,ϕ)=23​sin2θ​

entry.title: Antenna Parameters
entry.content:
On This Page

discussion of A brief overview of Maxwell’s equations with a focus on explaining what they mean instead of how they’re derived.

  • Radiation Efficiency
  • Directivity
  • Gain

A note on notation: All vector quantities will have a bar over them while scalar quantities will not. Unit vectors will be represented with a hat (e.g., x^\hat{x}x^) instead of a bar. Therefore, Aˉ=Bx^\bar{A}=B\hat{x}Aˉ=Bx^ describes a vector called Aˉ\bar{A}Aˉ pointing in the x-direction with a magnitude of BBB.

Radiation Efficiency

Antenna efficiency, e0e_0e0​, is the ratio of power radiated to the net power provided to an antenna.

e0=PradPin e_0 = \frac{P_{rad}}{P_{in}} e0​=Pin​Prad​​

Many factors can affect antenna efficiency, but some of the largest factors include inefficiencies due to impedance mismatches (eref)(e_{ref})(eref​), inefficiencies due to ohmic resistance (ec)(e_c)(ec​), and inefficiencies due to the dielectric around the antenna (ed)(e_d)(ed​). This inefficiencies all build into e0e_0e0​.

e0=erefeced e_0 = e_{ref}e_ce_d e0​=eref​ec​ed​

Where the product of ece_cec​ and ede_ded​ is often referred to as the radiation efficiency, ere_rer​.

Directivity

Directivity is the ratio of the radiation intensity, in some direction, to the average radiation intensity of an antenna. In the spherical coordinate system, this is expressed as:

D(θ,ϕ)=U(θ,ϕ)UavgD(\theta,\phi) = \frac{U(\theta,\phi)}{U_{avg}}D(θ,ϕ)=Uavg​U(θ,ϕ)​

Equivalently, it can be thought of as 4π4\pi4π times the radiation intensity divided by the total radiated power.

D(θ,ϕ)=4πU(θ,ϕ)Prad D(\theta, \phi) = 4\pi \frac{U(\theta, \phi)}{P_{rad}} D(θ,ϕ)=4πPrad​U(θ,ϕ)​

This definition is useful because it provides an intuitive link between radiated power and radiation intensity.

Gain

Gain is similar to directivity except that it includes the inefficiencies of an antenna. It is often provided in datasheets, instead of directivity, because of this. Gain is given by:

G(θ,ϕ)=erD(θ,ϕ) G(\theta, \phi) = e_rD(\theta, \phi) G(θ,ϕ)=er​D(θ,ϕ)

Where ere_rer​ is the radiation efficiency of the antenna.

Equivalently, it can be thought of as 4π4\pi4π times the radiation intensity divided by the total input power.

G(θ,ϕ)=4πU(θ,ϕ)Pin G(\theta, \phi) = 4\pi \frac{U(\theta, \phi)}{P_{in}} G(θ,ϕ)=4πPin​U(θ,ϕ)​

This definition is useful because it provides an intuitive link between input power and radiation intensity.

entry.title: Radiated Fields
entry.content:
On This Page

A variety of notes on the properties and characteristics of radiated fields in the far-field region.

  • What causes radiation?
  • Radiated Power Flow Density
  • Radiated Power
  • Radiation Intensity

A note on notation: All vector quantities will have a bar over them while scalar quantities will not. Unit vectors will be represented with a hat (e.g., x^\hat{x}x^) instead of a bar. Therefore, Aˉ=Bx^\bar{A}=B\hat{x}Aˉ=Bx^ describes a vector called Aˉ\bar{A}Aˉ pointing in the x-direction with a magnitude of BBB.

What causes radiation?

Radiation is the result of charges accelerating or decelerating over time. Recall that a charge creates an electric field around it that radiates outwards either forever or until influenced. When a charge moves, the electric field created by that charge also moves. As a result of Ampere’s Law, the changing electric field creates a magnetic field that wraps around the charge.

Because the electric field can only move so fast, the changes in the electric and magnetic fields propagate away from the moving charge. This is what we call radiation.

So: Radiation is caused by the acceleration or deceleration of charges.

Radiated Power Flow Density

The power flow density of an electromagnetic field, Sˉ\bar{S}Sˉ, is given by one-half of the cross product between Eˉ\bar{E}Eˉ and Hˉ∗\bar{H}^*Hˉ∗.

Sˉ=12Eˉ×Hˉ∗ \bar{S} = \frac{1}{2}\bar{E}\times\bar{H}^* Sˉ=21​Eˉ×Hˉ∗

Note that Sˉ\bar{S}Sˉ is:

  1. A vector quantity
  2. Not the amount of power at some location

Sˉ\bar{S}Sˉ represents the amount of power flowing in a particular direction through some area. It is not a measure of power, but rather power density.

Sˉ\bar{S}Sˉ is a complex value. The imaginary component, which represents the energy stored in the form of standing waves, has no time-average value and therefore does not represent power that can be delivered to some object. Only the real component can have a non-zero time-average value.

Radiated Power

To compute the power radiated by an electromagnetic field in a certain area, first find the field’s power flow density (Sˉ)(\bar{S})(Sˉ), take its real component (as only the real-component can have a non-zero time-average value), and integrate it over the area of interest.

Prad=12∫∫(Eˉ×Hˉ∗)⋅ds P_{rad} = \frac{1}{2}\int\int\left(\bar{E}\times\bar{H}^*\right)\cdot ds Prad​=21​∫∫(Eˉ×Hˉ∗)⋅ds

To find the total power radiated by an antenna, integrate the real component of Sˉ\bar{S}Sˉ over a sphere surrounding the antenna.

Prad,total=12∫∫(Eˉ×Hˉ∗)⋅ds=12∫02π∫0π(Eˉ×Hˉ∗)⋅(r^r2sin⁡θdθdϕ) P_{rad, total} = \frac{1}{2}\int\int\left(\bar{E}\times\bar{H}^*\right)\cdot ds = \frac{1}{2}\int_{0}^{2\pi}\int_{0}^{\pi}\left(\bar{E}\times\bar{H}^*\right)\cdot \left(\hat{r}r^2\sin\theta d\theta d\phi\right) Prad,total​=21​∫∫(Eˉ×Hˉ∗)⋅ds=21​∫02π​∫0π​(Eˉ×Hˉ∗)⋅(r^r2sinθdθdϕ)

Radiation Intensity

Radiation intensity, U(θ,ϕ)U(\theta, \phi)U(θ,ϕ), is the amount of power radiated in a direction per unit solid angle (in other words, per unit area).

U(θ,ϕ)=Sr(r,θ,ϕ)r2U(\theta,\phi) = S_r(r,\theta,\phi) r^2U(θ,ϕ)=Sr​(r,θ,ϕ)r2

entry.title: Maxwell’s Equations
entry.content:
On This Page

A brief overview of Maxwell’s equations with a focus on explaining what they mean instead of how they’re derived.

  1. Important Fields, Variables, and Phenomenon
    1. Polarization
    2. Material Permittivity
    3. Electric Displacement Field
    4. Polarization Density
    5. Electric Field
  2. The Equations
    1. Gauss’ Law
    2. Gauss’ Magnetic Law
    3. Faraday’s Law
    4. Ampere’s Law

A note on notation: Moving forward, all vector quantities will have a bar over them while scalar quantities will not. Unit vectors will be represented with a hat (e.g., x^\hat{x}x^) instead of a bar. Therefore, Aˉ=Bx^\bar{A}=B\hat{x}Aˉ=Bx^ describes a vector called Aˉ\bar{A}Aˉ pointing in the x-direction with a magnitude of BBB.

Important Fields, Variables, and Phenomenon

Polarization

Polarization refers to when charges in atoms shift position as a result of an electric force being applied to them. These charges come in two forms: Charges that are in the conduction band and flow freely (free charges) and charges that are in lower bands (bound charges). The shifting of these charges causes the atom to have a new net charge.

As an example of polarization, consider a parallel plate capacitor. When a voltage is applied across the capacitor, a field forms between the two plates. The atoms in the capacitor dielectric shift slightly so that their negative charges are closer to the positively-charged plate and their positive charges are closer to the negatively-charged plate. The dielectric material has polarized. When the external field is removed, a net charge will still exist across the dielectric as it takes time for the atoms to return to their original state.

Material Permittivity

The permittivity of a material, ϵ\epsilonϵ, is a metric for how much a material polarizes when an electric force acts upon it (for example, an electric field). It has the units of C/(V⋅m)C/(V\cdot m)C/(V⋅m), which can be thought of as “how many coulombs of charge are there, per meter, if I apply a voltage across a material.”

Electric Displacement Field

The electric displacement field, Dˉ\bar{D}Dˉ, is a measure of how much free charge exists and is moving in some direction, in a unit area. It has units of C/m2C/m^2C/m2.

Polarization Density

The polarization density, Pˉ\bar{P}Pˉ, of a material represents how much bound charge exists in a unit area. It has units of C/m2C/m^2C/m2.

Electric Field

The electric field, Eˉ\bar{E}Eˉ, at some location is a vector quantity that represents the force that a one-Coulomb test charge would experience if placed at that location. It has units of N/CN/CN/C or V/mV/mV/m.

The amount of electric field that exists at the surface of a material is dependent on the charge density of the material (that is, how many free- and bounded-charges exist in a unit area), as well as how much energy is required to move those charges (permittivity). Mathematically, Eˉ\bar{E}Eˉ may be expressed as:

Eˉ=Dˉ−Jˉϵ.\bar{E} = \frac{\bar{D} - \bar{J}}{\epsilon}.Eˉ=ϵDˉ−Jˉ​.

This can be interpreted as:

I have two sources of charge: Free charges and bound charges. I have Dˉ\bar{D}Dˉ free charges, in a unit area, moving in a direction. If I divide Dˉ\bar{D}Dˉ by the amount of energy it takes to move a charge one meter, I can obtain the total amount of energy being applied over one meter.

I also have Jˉ\bar{J}Jˉ in a unit area that are shifting to align with the external field. Their alignment will decrease the net field. If I divide Jˉ\bar{J}Jˉ by the amount of energy it takes to move charge one meter, I can obtain the total amount of energy being applied over one meter against the external field.

Importantly, electric field is very dependent on the material it is generated in. This is because the electric field is dependent on ϵ\epsilonϵ. This is a significant reason that we often Dˉ\bar{D}Dˉ instead.

Electric field has units of F/mF/mF/m or C/(V⋅m)C/(V\cdot m)C/(V⋅m).

The Equations

Maxwell’s equations are a collection of four equations that together describe the interaction of electric fields, magnetic fields, charges, and currents. They are often formulated in either integral or differential form. Differential form is easier to deal with when studying specific points in space and time, while integral form is more useful when dealing with …

The four equations, in differential form, are as follows:

Name Differential Equation
Gauss’ Law ∇⋅Dˉ=ρV\nabla\cdot\bar{D} = \rho_V∇⋅Dˉ=ρV​
Gauss’ Magnetism law ∇⋅Bˉ=0\nabla\cdot\bar{B} = 0∇⋅Bˉ=0
Faraday’s Law ∇×Eˉ=−∂Bˉ∂t\nabla\times\bar{E} = -\frac{\partial \bar{B}}{\partial t}∇×Eˉ=−∂t∂Bˉ​
Ampere’s Law ∇×Hˉ=∂Dˉ∂t+Jˉ\nabla\times\bar{H} = \frac{\partial \bar{D}}{\partial t} + \bar{J}∇×Hˉ=∂t∂Dˉ​+Jˉ

Where Dˉ\bar{D}Dˉ is electric displacement field, ρV\rho_VρV​ is electric charge density, Bˉ\bar{B}Bˉ is magnetic field, Eˉ\bar{E}Eˉ is electric field, Hˉ\bar{H}Hˉ is magnetic flux density, and Jˉ\bar{J}Jˉ is electric current density.

Gauss’ Law

Gauss’ Law states that the total amount of electric displacement field leaving some boundary is equal to the amount of charge contained within that boundary. Said in other words, the total number of free charges leaving some boundary is equal to the amount of charge contained within that boundary.

Gauss’ Magnetic Law

Gauss’ Magnetic Law states that the magnetic fields leaving a boundary must be equal to zero. In other words, either nothing exits or enters, or the same amount that exits also enters.

Faraday’s Law

Ampere’s Law
